title: US Healthcare Costs Decline for First Time in 20 Years
introText: US healthcare spending has declined for the first time in two decades, driven by drug price negotiations, telehealth adoption, and value-based care. Per capita spending fell 2% while quality metrics improved.

content.content: Per capita healthcare spending fell 2% to $12,500 in 2025, the first decline since 2003. Total spending fell to $4.3 trillion, defying decades of relentless growth.
Medicare drug price negotiations reduced prescription costs $100 billion. Telehealth lowered care delivery costs. Value-based payment models incentivized prevention over treatment.
Economists are cautiously optimistic that structural changes could bend the cost curve permanently. However, an aging population and new technologies may eventually reverse the trend.

summary: US healthcare costs decline for the first time in 20 years, driven by drug price negotiations, telehealth, and value-based care.
